title: FirstFT: Putin defends Ukraine invasion
text:
Vladimir Putin today defended Russia's invasion of Ukraine by claiming his country had to protect itself against an imminent attack creating what he called an “absolutely unacceptable threat for us directly on our borders”.

The Russian president was speaking at the annual Victory Day parade on Moscow's Red Square to mark the 77th anniversary of the Russian defeat of Nazi Germany.

Hours earlier Ukraine's president Volodymyr Zelensky challenged Moscow's claims that it alone defeated the Nazis and accused Russia's leadership of repeating the “horrific crimes of Hitler's regime” by waging a war of atrocities and land grabs against his country.

With the war now in its 11th week western governments unveiled a series of measures to further isolate Moscow after a meeting of G7 leaders yesterday.

The US targeted Gazprombank, Russia's third-largest lender, with sanctions for the first time and restricted the provision of professional services in Russia.

Japan joined a pledge by other G7 countries to phase out Russian oil imports at the G7 meeting. But Prime Minister Fumio Kishida again rejected calls to pull out of two big energy projects with Russia on the island of Sakhalin.

Meanwhile, the EU's top diplomat said the bloc should consider seizing frozen Russian foreign exchange reserves to help cover the costs of rebuilding Ukraine after the war.

Thanks for reading FirstFT Americas. Here's the rest of the day's news — Gordon

Five more stories in the news

1. CIA director says China ‘unsettled' by Ukraine war Bill Burns said the “bitter experience” of the first two months of the war in Ukraine had come as a surprise to the Chinese leadership and could be affecting its calculations with respect to Taiwan. Burns added that Xi's China was the “biggest geopolitical challenge we face over the long term as a country”, even though the threat from Putin's Russia could not be underestimated. Watch the full interview.

2. China's exporters battered by lockdowns and global inflation Chinese exports increased by just 3.9 per cent last month, a significant slowdown from the previous month in the latest sign of damage to the Chinese economy caused by President Xi Jinping's zero-Covid policy.

3. Defence companies face supply chain snags US defence contractors are preparing to increase production to meet extra demand from US and European governments following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. But supply chain issues, labour constraints and inflationary pressures could hold back efforts to scale up production, they have warned.

4. Spyware company NSO dodges questions NSO Group has stonewalled questions about whether it is operating legally, according to the US consultancy acting on behalf of the private equity fund that owns 70 per cent of the Israeli spyware company.

5. ETF investing plummets to lowest level since Covid crisis hit Purchases of exchange traded funds fell in April to their lowest level since the depths of the Covid-19 crisis as the war in Ukraine and spiralling global inflation sapped demand. Equity funds were particularly badly hit, with inflows slowing to a trickle of just $2.8bn, compared with $76.2bn a month earlier.

The day ahead

Outlook for markets Futures contracts tracking Wall Street's S&P 500 index fell 1.5 per cent, while those tracking the technology-heavy Nasdaq 100 dropped 1.7 per cent after shares in Asia and Europe began the new week in the red. US stock markets ended Friday with their fifth straight week of losses, the longest losing streak in more than a decade.

Company earnings Tyson Foods, one of the biggest meat producers in the US, releases earnings today. The company has faced transport and logistical problems linked to Covid-19 lockdowns in China and warned of rising prices. Analytics software company Palantir and retail investor favourite AMC Entertainment also report.

Monetary policy The Atlanta Branch of the Federal Reserve holds its signature policy and research event this week — the Financial Markets Conference. The conference, held in Florida, kicked off on Sunday and runs to Wednesday. Policy sessions today will discuss green returns and which central bank digital currency, if any, is right for the US. Separately, the Fed releases its twice yearly financial stability report at 4pm New York time.

Economic data Consumer prices in Mexico are forecast to have moderated to 0.58 per cent month on month in April, according to a Refinitiv survey of economists, from an increase of 1 per cent in March. Core inflation, which strips out volatile energy and food prices, is forecast to have accelerated slightly to 0.75 per cent from the previous month.

Philippines election Filipinos have begun voting in a national election that pits the son and namesake of late dictator Ferdinand Marcos and his running mate Sara Duterte, daughter of incumbent Rodrigo Duterte, against a progressive candidate promising a break with the country's increasingly authoritarian governance.

Northern Ireland talks The UK government will begin talks to try and coax pro-British unionists to join the region's government after a historic victory for the nationalist Sinn Féin party in last week's regional elections.

Pulitzer Prize The 106th annual Pulitzer Prize winners and finalists will be announced, with awards in journalism, drama, letters and music.

FT's Future of the Car summit, which runs from today until Thursday, features Tesla founder Elon Musk, who will be speaking and taking questions, along with a host of other industry leaders. Register here.

What else we're reading

Money managers in demand The industry for outsourcing investment mandates is booming as challenging markets, compliance regulations and rising costs push big asset owners to seek help. The sector has more than doubled in size since 2016 to $2.46tn in global assets under management.

  • More on investment: The concept of acronym investing is coming apart, Ruchir Sharma writes. The recent unbundling of the Faangs is much like the fall of the Brics emerging markets a decade ago.

The world needs a 12-step programme for better trade The World Trade Organization is broken, and the first step towards a solution is admitting there is a problem with the old model of globalisation. The world needs a newer, faster way to resolve trade disputes and balance international trade with domestic politics, argues Rana Foroohar.

US buyout group behind the winning Chelsea bid A financing consortium led by Todd Boehly emerged victorious over the weekend in its bid to buy Chelsea Football Club for £4.25bn, the biggest sum ever paid for a football club. But it was an unusual manoeuvre by one of the buyout industry's least known success stories that made it possible.

Explaining Web3 to beginners Web3 — the new internet — is built with blockchain technology, which supports digital assets such as cryptocurrencies. However, its complexity has been a barrier to participation. New economy investor June Angelides offers a guide to getting a handle on it and discovering its potential.

Bleisure's moment in the sun The ugly portmanteau describes a cross between business travel and leisure, Emma Jacobs writes. It is hardly new to tack a weekend of sightseeing on to a conference, but as business travel picks up and Covid-19 curbs end, there are reasons to believe this year its time has come.

How To Spend It

Jony Ive, the former chief designer at Apple who runs his own agency based in San Francisco, edited the latest edition of How To Spend It. In a series of features Ive focuses on the magic of silver (his dad was a silversmith) and shares 12 tools of his trade.
